title: 115_hr4010
content: The Act is titled the "Congressional Subpoena Compliance and Enforcement Act of 2017" and focuses on the enforcement of congressional subpoenas. The "Congressional Subpoena Compliance and Enforcement Act of 2017" amends Chapter 85 of title 28, United States Code, by adding a new section 1365a. This section outlines special rules for civil actions brought by Congress against subpoena recipients for non-compliance, specifying the jurisdiction and expediting the disposition of such cases. The "Congressional Subpoena Compliance and Enforcement Act of 2017" expedites the disposition of civil actions brought by Congress against subpoena recipients for non-compliance. If a three-judge court is requested, the case will be heard by a three-judge court and appealable only to the Supreme Court. Monetary penalties can be imposed against government agency heads for willful non-compliance with congressional subpoenas. The "Congressional Subpoena Compliance and Enforcement Act of 2017" prohibits the use of government funds to pay monetary penalties imposed by the court for willful non-compliance with congressional subpoenas. Failure to comply with producing a privilege log may result in a waiver of privilege. The term 'Government agency' is defined for this section as an executive department, independent establishment, commission, board, bureau, division, or office in the executive branch, or other agency of the Federal Government, including wholly or partly owned Government corporations. SEC. 3. COMPLIANCE WITH CONGRESSIONAL SUBPOENAS. Amends Chapter 7 of title II of the Revised Statutes of the United States by adding a new section requiring a response to congressional subpoenas. The new section requires recipients of congressional subpoenas to appear and testify or produce records. If records are withheld, a log must be provided with details such as legal basis, type of record, subject matter, date, author, and addressee. The new section mandates recipients of congressional subpoenas to provide detailed information about withheld records, including legal basis, type, subject, date, author, and recipient. If records are missing, the recipient must explain the circumstances of their absence. The new section requires electronic records to be produced in their original format and delivered on a storage device. It also defines the term 'record' to include various types of requested items in a congressional subpoena. The Act clarifies that Congress' authority to enforce compliance with subpoenas remains intact and does not imply acceptance of any privilege for noncompliance. Passed by the House of Representatives on October 23, 2017.
